messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Chris Dollin <chris.dollin@...> wrote:
> Read Michael Feathers' book /Working Effectively with Legacy Code/.
I read the sample chapter on the net, it's very interesting and
practical. Must be the next book to order...

> I'd suggest classes which are likely to be worked on "soon". Those are,
> after all, the ones which you might otherwise break, and for which
> unit tests will add most value.
>
> It's tempting to start with "easy" ones, but you run the risk of writing
> tests for things that won't change and won't break, and you'd gain an
> unrealistic view of how easy it is(n't) to add tests post-hoc.

Yes, actually writing JUnit tests is just another development
task/cycle you must put efforts in to explore bugs at unit-level,
isn't it. Perhaps the TDD methodology mixes these two development
cycles nattily...

It would be interesting to see a statistics how many bugs an
OO-project has at unit-level and how many at integration-level (during
cooperation of objects).

Thanks Chris,
csaba
